title: ğŸ”± Codebase Overview
content:
Eask consists of two components: a command-line tool (the Eask CLI), and Elisp scripts.
The CLI, is used to find the corresponding lisp file and feed it into the Emacs executable. It would parse all options and convert them to Emacs understandable options on the lisp scripts end. It is written in plain JavaScript, the main file is located in src/util.js.
The Elisp scripts, is used to do the actual execution for each command that passes through the CLI. All commands are split into its file and are organized in the lisp folder. It is written in plain Emacs Lisp, the main file is located in lisp/_prepare.el.
   ğŸ–¥ï¸ CLI & Yargs ğŸ“œ Elisp Script ğŸ“‚ Project Structure  â™»ï¸ Execution Order for Eask        ğŸ–¥ï¸ CLI & Yargs     The yargs command file is written in JavaScript, and located under the cmds folder. Each file under, will be named with convention [command_name].js. This file should define basic command-line parsing rules and correctly prepare data to feed the Emacs session.
Let’s look at the file cmds/core/archives.js:
exports.command = ['archives', 'sources']; // alias to sources exports.desc = 'list out all package archives'; exports.handler = async (argv) => { await UTIL.e_call(argv, 'core/archives'); }; This is a standard yargs command file, which contains all the information we need to pass it to the Emacs session.
 exports.command is the argument pattern, but it also accepts alias (array) exports.desc is the command description exports.handler is an asynchronous function that handles command execution UTIL is a global variable that points to the src/util.js module. 'core/archives' is the elisp file under lisp folder (without .el extension).  eask is a JavaScript file that holds all our global options.
yargs .usage('Usage: eask <command> [options..]') .help( 'help', 'Show usage instructions.' ) .option('global', { description: 'change default workspace to ~/.emacs.d/', alias: 'g', type: 'boolean', }) .. For local options, please use exports.builder and specify under its command file.
See yargs/docs/advanced.md, the official documentation for more information and getting a better explanation would help!
ğŸ“œ Elisp Script     Elisp scripts are located under the lisp folder and will wait to get called by the CLI. All Elisp scripts are written in Emacs Lisp and should have a similar structure below:
(load (expand-file-name "../_prepare.el" (file-name-directory (nth 1 (member "-scriptload" command-line-args)))) nil t) (eask-start (message "PWD is %s" default-directory)) See Development API section for more information!
ğŸ“‚ Project Structure     There are three places you need to look into it:
 eask file at the root of the project cmds folder with all available commands lisp folder with all elisp code  eask is the node entry, and the main yargs definition! cmds and lisp folders are command files that correspond to each other.
â™»ï¸ Execution Order for Eask     Eask is executed this way:
 Eask environment builds sandbox and reads Eask file information Emacs configuration is only being executed when -g option is enabled before hooks are hooks run before command task command execution is the primary command task after hooks are hooks run after command task

title: ğŸ”¨ Developing Eask
content:
ğŸš© Prerequisites ğŸ“ Building ğŸ“ˆ Testing        ğŸš© Prerequisites     To make changes to Eask, you should have:
 Node.js the development environment. npm for the package manager. yargs for parsing the command-line. Emacs, 26.1 or above!  ğŸ“ Building     To build the development environment, you would have to install Eask using the source method. (Not install through NPM) Make sure you have setup the environment PATH variable, so you can call eask from the terminal.
After you have step through the installation, try:
$ eask locate It should print out the location of your working Eask workspace. You should be able to identify the Eask workspace, even you have multiple Eask version installed!
ğŸ“ˆ Testing     Eask does not offer local testing, all our tests are accomplished using GitHub Actions. Please fork our repository, and push your changes to your fork. GitHub Actions should pick up the test for you!
Make sure you have GitHub Actions enabled in your repository (forked). Got to Settings -> Actions -> General -> Actions Permissions; make sure you have checked the correct options.

title: âœ’ï¸ Documentation
content:
ğŸš© Prerequisites ğŸ“ Setup        Eask includes a comprehensive user guide. Please try to extend it accordingly while you implement new features.
The documentation is written in Markdown, using Hugo and GitHub Pages. The former is the static site generator, and the latter is the static web pages hosting service from GitHub.
ğŸ’¡ You can find all our documentation under the docs/content/ folder.  ğŸš© Prerequisites     To make changes to documentation, you should have:
 hugo executable; the static site generator.  ğŸ“ Setup     To setup the website locally, you need to first navigate to the docs/ folder.
$ cd path/to/eask/docs/ Then run the hugo command:
$ hugo server And that’s it! Now you can open the browser with the URL localhost:1313. ğŸ‰
ğŸ’¡ You can specify -D option if you consider writing a draft.

title: ğŸ“­ Pull Request
content:
If all tests have passed, and the Eask can operate normally with updated documentation (if any), please send us a pull request with your changes. ğŸŠ
ğŸ§ª Tests Explained     This has moved to the repository README.md file.
Please visit https://github.com/emacs-eask/eask#-testing.

title: âš™ï¸ Emacs Configuration
content:
Eask is the magic file that eask will read it as the init file in Emacs. The syntaxes are similar to the Cask file, but different.
(package "Emacs configuration's name" "0.1.0" "Your Emacs configuration's description") ; optional (website-url "https://github.com/owner/repo") (keywords "config") (package-file "init.el") ; optional (files "early-init.el" "init.el" "lisp/*.el" "site-lisp/*.el") (source "gnu") (source "melpa") (depends-on "emacs" "26.1") (depends-on "auto-complete") (depends-on "dash") (depends-on "f") (depends-on "flycheck") (depends-on "helm") (depends-on "magit") (depends-on "popup") (depends-on "projectile") (depends-on "s") (depends-on "smartparens") (depends-on "yasnippet") ğŸ’¡ You would need to use -g or –global option to manage your configuration’s packages!

title: ğŸ’¿ GitHub Actions
content:
ğŸ’¾ Setup Eask locally      Here is an example using the GitHub Actions service.
jobs:test:runs-on:${{ matrix.os }}strategy:matrix:os:[ubuntu-latest, macos-latest, windows-latest]emacs-version:[27.2,snapshot]steps:- uses:actions/checkout@v2# Install Emacs- uses:jcs090218/setup-emacs@masterwith:version:${{ matrix.emacs-version }}# You need node for Eask- uses:actions/setup-node@v2with:node-version:'16'# Install Eask- uses:emacs-eask/setup-eask@masterwith:version:'snapshot'- name:Run testsrun:|eask install eask compile eask lint packageThis example is testing your Emacs Lisp package in the below environment;
 Emacs: 27.2 and snapshot Node: 16.x Eask: snapshot (latest)  with these following actions,
 setup-emacs to install Emacs setup-node to set up Node and npm setup-eask to install desired Eask version  ğŸ’¾ Setup Eask locally     You can install Eask locally using scripts from .github/scripts/setup-eask (Unix) or .github/scripts/setup-eask.ps1 (Windows).
- uses:actions/checkout@v2- name:Prepare Eask (Unix)if:matrix.os == 'ubuntu-latest' || matrix.os == 'macos-latest'run:|chmod -R 777 ./ .github/scripts/setup-eask- name:Prepare Eask (Windows)if:matrix.os == 'windows-latest'run:.github/scripts/setup-eask.ps1

title: ğŸ”° Quick Start
content:
Step 1: Setup NodeJS runtime and npm Step 2: Install Eask Step 3: Navigate to an existing project or create a new project Step 4: Create Eask-file Step 5: Start the pacakge development Step 6: Manage package archives Step 7: Add some dependencies Step 8: Install dependencies See Also      Using Eask as your Emacs package management tool.
The installation are cross-platform, using npm. For instruction about how to install Eask with other methods, see install.
It is required to have Git installed to run this tutorial.
 Step 1: Setup NodeJS runtime and npm     Please check out their official site here and install NodeJS and npm corresponds to your current operating system
ğŸ’¡ If you don’t prefer NodeJS and npm, you can install with binary from our release page.  Step 2: Install Eask     $ npm install -g @emacs-eask/eask To verify your new install:
$ eask --version Step 3: Navigate to an existing project or create a new project     If you already have an existing elisp project, navigate to the project root folder.
$ cd /path/to/project/dir/ To create one:
$ eask create project-name It should create a folder named project-name in your current working directory.
Step 4: Create Eask-file     Skip this step if you chose to create project with eask create!
Otherwise, to create Eask-file in the existing project:
$ eask init You will be asked with some questions about the package you are going to create:
package name: (your-project) version: (1.0.0) description: Your project description! entry point: (your-project.el) emacs version: (26.1) website: https://example.com/project-url/ keywords: tools example About to write to /path/to/project/Eask: (package "your-project" "1.0.0" "Your project description!") (website-url "https://example.com/project-url/") (keywords "tools" "example") (package-file "your-project.el") (source "gnu") (depends-on "emacs" "26.1") Is this OK? (yes) yes â You should be able to see an Eask file in your project folder. ğŸ‰ğŸŠ
Step 5: Start the pacakge development     To check your package information, run:
$ eask info You should be able to see the following information:
Running Eask in the development environment Press Ctrl+C to cancel. Executing script inside Emacs... âœ“ Checking Emacs version 29.0.50... done! âœ“ Checking system windows-nt... done! âœ“ Loading Eask file in /path/to/project/Eask... done! your-package (1.0.0) | deps: 0 | devDeps: 0 your package description entry: your-package-file.el kind: single dist .total-files: 0 .unpacked-size: 0 From the start, you would not have any dependencies and devDependencies (0 by default)!
Step 6: Manage package archives     You can manage package archives by using the source directive in your Eask-file.
(source "gnu") ; default (source "melpa") ; Add package archives ğŸ’¡ See DSL/source for more information!  Step 7: Add some dependencies     You can add dependenices by using depends-on directive in your Eask-file.
... (depends-on "f") (depends-on "ht") ğŸ’¡ Make sure the dependency you add are available in the package archives!
Or else you would get an error `package-name-' is unavailable!
 Step 8: Install dependencies     Now we can install dependencies we have specified in the Eask-file:
$ eask install-deps You should see Eask executed correctly with the similar output below:
Running Eask in the development environment Press Ctrl+C to cancel. Executing script inside Emacs... âœ“ Checking Emacs version 29.0.50... done! âœ“ Checking system windows-nt... done! âœ“ Loading Eask file in /path/to/project/Eask... done! Loading package information... done Installing 2 package dependencies... - Installing f (20220405.1534)... done - Installing ht (20210119.741)... done (Total of 2 dependencies installed, 0 skipped) See Also      Commands and options Domain Specific Language Basic Usage

title: ğŸ”­ Finding Emacs
content:
By default, Eask will use whatever the Emacs version exists in your environment path. Use emacs –version to check your Emacs version.
There is currently no way to specify an Emacs version to execute.

title: Domain Specific Language
content:
This document provides a reference on the DSL.
 ğŸš© Package metadata  ğŸ” package (name version description) ğŸ” website-url (url) ğŸ” keywords (&rest keywords)   ğŸš© Package contents  ğŸ” package-file (file version description) ğŸ” files (&rest patterns)   ğŸš© Dependencies  ğŸ” source (alias) ğŸ” source (name url) ğŸ” source-priority (name priority) ğŸ” depends-on (package-name &optional minimum-version) ğŸ” depends-on (package-name &rest recipe) ğŸ” development (&rest body) ğŸ” load-paths (&rest paths) ğŸ” exec-paths (&rest paths)      ğŸš© Package metadata     ğŸ” package (name version description)     Declare a package with the given name, version, and description:
(package "ert-runner" "0.7.0" "Opinionated Ert testing workflow") All arguments are strings. The version must be a version understood by Emacs' built-in version-to-list.
ğŸ” website-url (url)     Declare the package website.
(website-url "https://github.com/owner/repo.git") ğŸ” keywords (&rest keywords)     Declare package keywords.
(keywords "tool" "utility" "emacs") ğŸš© Package contents     ğŸ” package-file (file version description)     Define this package and its runtime dependencies from the package headers of a file (used only for package development).
(package-file "foo.el") ğŸ” files (&rest patterns)     Specify list of files that are included in this project.
(files "foo.el") (files "*.el" "core/*.el") ğŸš© Dependencies     ğŸ” source (alias)     ğŸ” source (name url)     Add a package archive to install dependencies from.
(source "gnu") (source "gnu" "https://elpa.gnu.org/packages/") Available aliases:
 gnu (https://elpa.gnu.org/packages/) nongnu (https://elpa.nongnu.org/nongnu/) celpa (https://celpa.conao3.com/) jcs-elpa (https://jcs-emacs.github.io/jcs-elpa/packages/) marmalade (https://marmalade-repo.org/packages/) melpa (https://melpa.org/packages/) melpa-stable (https://stable.melpa.org/packages/) org (https://orgmode.org/elpa/) shmelpa (https://shmelpa.commandlinesystems.com/packages/)  ğŸ’¡ Use –insecure to make https to http, but not recommended  ğŸ” source-priority (name priority)     Set archive priority.
(source-priority "gnu" 5) ğŸ” depends-on (package-name &optional minimum-version)     ğŸ” depends-on (package-name &rest recipe)     Specify a dependency of this package.
Specify dependencies that are listed in archives:
(depends-on "emacs" "26.1") (depends-on "dash") (depends-on "company") Specify dependencies in recipe format:
(depends-on "auto-rename-tag" :repo "jcs-elpa/auto-rename-tag" :fetcher 'github) (depends-on "lsp-ui" :repo "emacs-lsp/lsp-ui" :fetcher 'github :files '(:defaults "lsp-ui-doc.html" "resources")) ğŸ’¡ Install dependencies with command eask install-deps!  ğŸ” development (&rest body)     Scope all depends-on expressions in body to development.
(development (depends-on "ert-runner") (depends-on "elsa")) ğŸ’¡ You would need to specify the –dev option for development dependencies!  ğŸ” load-paths (&rest paths)     Specify paths to add to load-path
(load-paths "/lisp/") ğŸ” exec-paths (&rest paths)     Specify paths to add to exec-path
(load-paths "/bin/")

title: ğŸ’¾ Install Eask
content:
This document guides you through the installation of Eask.
   ğŸ’¾ Quick Install  Binary (Cross-platform) npm Homebrew (macOS or Linux) MacPorts (macOS) Chocolatey (Windows) Scoop (Windows)   ğŸ’¾ Source  ğŸš© Prerequisite Tools ğŸ¡ Setup        ğŸ’¾ Quick Install     Binary (Cross-platform)     Download the appropriate version for your platform from Eask Releases. Once downloaded, the binary can be run from anywhere. You donâ€™t need to install it into a global location. This works well for shared hosts and other systems where you donâ€™t have a privileged account.
Ideally, you should install it somewhere in your PATH for easy use. /usr/local/bin is the most probable location.
npm     If you have npm installed on your machine, you can install Eask with the following one-liner:
$ npm install -g @emacs-eask/eask Homebrew (macOS or Linux)     WIP
MacPorts (macOS)     WIP
Chocolatey (Windows)     If you have Chocolatey installed on your machine, you can install Eask with the following one-liner:
$ chcoc install eask Scoop (Windows)     WIP
ğŸ’¾ Source     ğŸš© Prerequisite Tools      Git Node.js npm  Alternatively, you can clone it directly from this repo
# clone the repo $ git clone https://github.com/emacs-eask/eask # change the working directory to eask $ cd eask # install the requirements $ npm install ğŸ¡ Setup     Make sure you set up the environment path variable according to your system,
On Linux/macOS,
export PATH="$HOME/eask/bin:$PATH" On Windows,
set PATH=%PATH%;c:/path/to/eask/bin Once you have set it up correctly, try eask --version then you should see the current eask’s version number! ğŸ‰ ğŸŠ

title: ğŸ“¦ Package Development
content:
Eask is the magic file that eask will read it as the init file in Emacs. The syntaxes are similar to the Cask file, but different.
(package "your-package" "0.1.0" "Your package description") (website-url "https://github.com/owner/repo") (keywords "example" "tool") (package-file "your-package-file.el") (source "gnu") (depends-on "emacs" "26.1") (depends-on "dash") (depends-on "f") (depends-on "s")

title: ğŸ”¨ Basic Usage
content:
Easkâ€™s CLI is fully featured but simple to use, even for those who have very limited experience working from the command line.
The following is a description of the most common commands you will use while developing your Eask project. See the Commands and options for a comprehensive view of Easkâ€™s CLI.
Once you have installed Eask, make sure it is in your PATH. You can test that Eask has been installed correctly via the help command:
$ eask help The output you see in your console should be similar to the following:
eask is the main command, used to manage your Emacs dependencies Eask is a command-line tool that helps you build, lint, and test Emacs Lisp packages. Usage: eask <command> [options..] Commands: activate [files..] activate package; use to test package activation archives list out all package archives [aliases: sources] autoloads generate autoloads file clean-all do all cleaning tasks clean-elc remove byte compiled files generated by cask build clean clean up local .eask directory compile [names..] byte compile all Emacs Lisp files in the package [aliases: build] concat [names..] concatenate all elisp files [aliases: concatenate] create <name> create a new elisp project [aliases: new] emacs [args..] execute emacs with the appropriate environment eval [form] evaluate lisp form with a proper PATH path print the PATH (exec-path) from workspace [aliases: exec-path] exec [args..] execute command with correct environment PATH set up files print the list of all package files info display information about the current package init create new Eask file in current directory install-deps automatically install package dependencies [aliases: install-dependencies, prepare] install [names..] install packages keywords list available keywords that can be used in the header section lint <type> run linter list-all list all available packages list list all installed packages load-path print the load-path from workspace load [files..] load files outdated show all outdated dependencies package-directory print path to package directory package [destination] Build a package artifact, and put it into the given destination pkg-file generate -pkg file recipe suggest a recipe format refresh download package archives reinstall [names..] reinstall packages search [queries..] search packages test <type> run test uninstall [names..] uninstall packages [aliases: delete] upgrade [names..] upgrade packages check-eask [files..] run eask checker locate print out Eask installed location upgrade-eask upgrade Eask itself [aliases: upgrade-self] Options: --version Show version number [boolean] --help Show usage instructions [boolean] -g, --global change default workspace to ~/.emacs.d/ [boolean] -f, --force enable force flag [boolean] --development, --dev turn on development mode [boolean] --debug turn on debug mode [boolean] --strict report error instead of warnings [boolean] --allow-error continue the executioon even there is error reported [boolean] --insecure allow insecure connection [boolean] --timestamps log with timestamps [boolean] --log-level log with level [boolean] --elapsed-time, --et show elapsed time between each operation [boolean] --no-color disable color output [boolean] --proxy update proxy for HTTP and HTTPS to host [string] --http-proxy update proxy for HTTP to host [string] --https-proxy update proxy for HTTPS to host [string] --no-proxy set no-proxy to host [string] -v, --verbose set verbosity from 0 to 4 [number] For more information, find the manual at https://emacs-eask.github.io/ The eask Command     The most common usage is probably to run eask with your current directory being the input directory.

title: ğŸš© Commands and options
content:
ğŸš© Core  ğŸ” eask create ğŸ” eask init ğŸ” eask info ğŸ” eask install-deps ğŸ” eask install ğŸ” eask uninstall ğŸ” eask package ğŸ” eask compile ğŸ” eask autoloads ğŸ” eask pkg-file ğŸ” eask package-directory ğŸ” eask path ğŸ” eask load-path ğŸ” eask files ğŸ” eask exec ğŸ” eask emacs ğŸ” eask eval ğŸ” eask load ğŸ” eask activate ğŸ” eask recipe ğŸ” eask keywords ğŸ” eask concate   ğŸš© Management  ğŸ” eask archives ğŸ” eask search ğŸ” eask upgrade ğŸ” eask list ğŸ” eask list-all ğŸ” eask outdated ğŸ” eask refresh   ğŸš© Cleaning  ğŸ” eask clean ğŸ” eask clean-elc ğŸ” eask clean-all   ğŸš© Linter  ğŸ” eask lint package ğŸ” eask lint checkdoc ğŸ” eask lint elint ğŸ” eask lint elsa ğŸ” eask lint indent ğŸ” eask lint keywords ğŸ” eask lint declare ğŸ” eask lint regexps   ğŸš© Testing  ğŸ” eask test ert ğŸ” eask test ert-runner ğŸ” eask test buttercup   ğŸš© Utilities  ğŸ” eask upgrade-eask ğŸ” eask locate   ğŸš© Checker  ğŸ” eask check-eask   ğŸš© Global Options  ğŸ” –global, -g ğŸ” –development, –dev ğŸ” –force, -f ğŸ” –debug ğŸ” –strict ğŸ” –allow-error ğŸ” –insecure ğŸ” –timestamps ğŸ” –log-level ğŸ” –no-color ğŸ” –elapsed-time ğŸ” –proxy <proxy> ğŸ” –http-proxy <proxy> ğŸ” –no-proxy <pattern> ğŸ” –verbose, -v <integer> ğŸ” –version ğŸ” –help      The general syntax of the eask program is:
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] [COMMAND] [COMMAND-OPTIONS] [COMMAND-ARGUMENTS] ğŸš© Core     ğŸ” eask create     Create an elisp project with the default Eask-file and CI/CD support.
ğŸ’¡ The template project is located in https://github.com/emacs-eask/template-elisp  ğŸ” eask init     Eask will generate file like:
(package "PACKAGE-NAME" "VERSION" "YOUR PACKAGE SUMMARY") (package-file "PACKAGE-FILE") (source "gnu") (depends-on "emacs" "26.1") ğŸ’¡ See section Examples for more information!  ğŸ” eask info     Show information about the project or configuration.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] info ğŸ” eask install-deps     To install all dependencies.
Alias: install-dependencies, prepare
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] install-deps [--dev] ğŸ’¡ Specify option [–dev] to install dependencies from the development scope.  ğŸ” eask install     To install packages.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] install [PACKAGES..] Install packages by specifying arguments:
$ eask install auto-complete helm magit Or else, it will install the package from the current development:
$ eask install ğŸ” eask uninstall     To uninstall/delete packages.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] uninstall [PACKAGES..] Uninstall packages by specifying arguments:
$ eask uninstall dash f s Or else, it will uninstall the package from the current development:
$ eask uninstall ğŸ” eask package     Build the package artifact.
$ eask package [DESTINATION] If [DESTINATION] is not specified, it will export to the /dist folder by default.
ğŸ” eask compile     Byte-compile files.
$ eask compile [FILES..] Compile files by specifying arguments:
$ eask compile file-1.el file-2.el Or compile files that are already specified in your Eask-file.
$ eask compile ğŸ” eask autoloads     Generate autoload file.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] autoloads ğŸ” eask pkg-file     Write a package descriptor file to project-pkg.el in the project root.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] pkg-file project is the project name, as declared in Eask-file. See Multi-file Packages (elisp) for details.
ğŸ” eask package-directory     Print path to package directory, where all dependencies are installed.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] package-directory ğŸ” eask path     Print the PATH environment variable of this project.
Alias: exec-path
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] path ğŸ” eask load-path     Print the load path containing the dependencies of the current project.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] load-path ğŸ” eask files     Print the list of all package files.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] files ğŸ” eask exec     Execute the system command with the given arguments.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] exec [COMMAND] [ARGUMENTS ...] ğŸ” eask emacs     Execute emacs with the appropriate environment
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] emacs [ARGUMENTS ...] ğŸ” eask eval     Evaluate FORM as a lisp form.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] eval [FORM] ğŸ” eask load     Load Emacs Lisp files in order.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] load [FILES..] ğŸ” eask activate     Activate package; use to test the package activation
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] activate [FILES..] ğŸ’¡ You can pass in [FILES..] so you can test your package activation fully!
[FILES..] will be loaded after the package is activated.
 ğŸ” eask recipe     Suggest a recipe format
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] recipe [FILES..] ğŸ” eask keywords     List available keywords that can be used in the header section.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] keywords ğŸ” eask concate     Concatenate all Emacs Lisp files into one big file.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] concate [FILES..] ğŸš© Management     ğŸ” eask archives     List out all package archives.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] archives ğŸ” eask search     Search packages from archives.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] search [QUEIRES..] ğŸ” eask upgrade     Upgrade all packages.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] upgrade ğŸ” eask list     List out all installed packages.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] list [--depth] ğŸ” eask list-all     List out all available packages.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] list-all [--depth] ğŸ” eask outdated     List out all outdated packages.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] outdated [--depth] ğŸ” eask refresh     Download package archives.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] refresh ğŸš© Cleaning     ğŸ” eask clean     Delete .eask from the current workspace.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] clean â›”ï¸ Don’t specify the option --global, -g, or else it will delete your entire ~/.emacs.d
$ eask clean -g ğŸ” eask clean-elc     Delete all .elc files. This would respect to your Eask file.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] clean-elc ğŸ” eask clean-all     This command is combination of all other clean commands.
 clean clean-elc  $ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] clean-all ğŸš© Linter     Commands that lint your Emacs package.
ğŸ” eask lint package     Lint package using package-lint.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] lint package [FILES..] ğŸ” eask lint checkdoc     Run checkdoc.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] lint checkdoc [FILES..] ğŸ” eask lint elint     Run elint.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] lint elint [FILES..] ğŸ” eask lint elsa     Run elsa.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] lint lint elsa [FILES..] ğŸ” eask lint indent     Run indent-lint.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] lint indent [FILES..] ğŸ” eask lint keywords     Run keywords checker.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] lint keywords ğŸ” eask lint declare     $ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] lint declare [FILES..] ğŸ” eask lint regexps     Alias: lint relint
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] lint regexps [FILES..] ğŸš© Testing     ğŸ” eask test ert     $ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] test ert [FILES..] ğŸ” eask test ert-runner     $ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] test ert-runner ğŸ” eask test buttercup     $ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] test buttercup ğŸš© Utilities     Other helper commands.
ğŸ” eask upgrade-eask     Upgrade Eask to the latest version.
Alias: upgrade-self
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] upgrade-eask ğŸ’¡ This will only work if you install it from source!  ğŸ” eask locate     Show Eask installed location
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] locate ğŸš© Checker     Commands to check your Eask-file.
ğŸ” eask check-eask     Lint an Eask-file.
$ eask [GLOBAL-OPTIONS] check-eask ğŸš© Global Options     The following options are available on all Eask commands:
ğŸ” –global, -g     Use ~/.emacs.d/ instead of package development environment. This is used for Emacs configuration.
Install package auto-complete for your Emacs configuration:
$ eask -g [COMMAND] ğŸ” –development, –dev     Notify command with development scope enabled.
If we attempt to install development dependencies:
$ eask --dev [COMMAND] ğŸ” –force, -f     Force command’s execution.
Force to uninstall the package dash even it’s a dependency from another packages
$ eask -f [COMMAND] ğŸ” –debug     Enable debug information.
This is equivalent to:
(setq debug-on-error t) ğŸ” –strict     Trigger error instead of warnings.
For instance, in eask compile:
(setq byte-compile-error-on-warn t) ğŸ” –allow-error     Continue the execution without killing the Emacs.
ğŸ” –insecure     Connect archives with HTTP instead of HTTPS.
ğŸ” –timestamps     Enable/Disable timestamps.
ğŸ” –log-level     Enable/Disable log header.
ğŸ” –no-color     Disable color output.
ğŸ” –elapsed-time     Show elapsed time between each operation
ğŸ” –proxy <proxy>     Set Emacs proxy for HTTP and HTTPS:
$ eask --proxy "localhost:8888" [COMMAND] ğŸ” –http-proxy <proxy>     Set Emacs proxy for HTTP only.
 –https-proxy <proxy>
 Set Emacs proxy for HTTPS only.
ğŸ” –no-proxy <pattern>     Do not use a proxy for any URL matching pattern.
<pattern>is an Emacs regular expression.
ğŸ” –verbose, -v <integer>     Set verbosity from 0 to 4.
$ eask --verbose 4 [COMMAND] ğŸ” –version     Show version number.
ğŸ” –help     Show help.

title: ğŸ—ï¸ Directory Structure
content:
Directory Structure Explained      Running the eask create generator from the command-line will create a directory with the following structure:
. â”œâ”€â”€ .github/workflows/test.yml â”œâ”€â”€ .gitignore â”œâ”€â”€ Makefile â”œâ”€â”€ Eask â”œâ”€â”€ README.md â””â”€â”€ {package-file}.el Directory Structure Explained     The following is a high-level overview of each of the files.
.github/workflows/test.yml
GitHub actions workflow file that is read by GitHub Actions. This file has setups the basic environment for you to test your elisp project. Like, such as installing Emacs, setup Eask, etc.
.gitignore
Gitignore file, to ignore files you don’t like to include from your repository. By default, it already excludes files and directories that are generated by Eask.
Makefile
Makefile that has already included basic tests for your package. It now has the following tasks be default:
 Test build (packaging + installing) Test byte-compile Test checkdoc (style checker) Test lint (package linter)  README.md
The generated document file. This is used to display the main page from your repository.
{package-file}.el
This is the main package file; where you should write your elisp code. If you attempt to create a multiple-file packages; you would need to edit the Eask-file accordingly.

title: âš–ï¸ Real project examples
content:
These are some projects and configurations using Eask:
   Configuration Packages ELPA      Configuration      jcs-emacs  Packages      auto-highlight-symbol emacs-dashboard flycheck-languagetool grammarly popup-el line-reminder  ELPA      jcs-elpa

title: ğŸ”§ Advanced Usage
content:
Eask is just a regular Emacs Lisp file and should be read from Emacs itself! You can do:
; Regular Eask file content... (setq byte-compile-error-on-warn t) ; Signal error if warning occurred eask provides some hooks which enable you to execute code before and after each command. The hooks look like so:
eask-{`before`/`after`}-{`command_name`}-hook For example, to consider warnings as errors when byte-compiling with the command eask compile:
(add-hook 'eask-before-compile-hook (lambda () (setq byte-compile-error-on-warn t))) This is also equivalent to option --strict:
$ eask compile [FILES..] --strict Or hooks run on every command:
 eask-before-command-hook eask-after-command-hook

title: Development API
content:
This document provides a reference to the public Eask API, which you may use in your projects and extensions to Eask.

eask-checker-p () ğŸ” Function: eask-script (script) ğŸ” Function: eask-load (script) ğŸ” Function: eask-call (script) ğŸ” Macro: eask-defvc< (version &rest body) ğŸ” Macro: eask–silent (&rest body) ğŸ” Macro: eask–unsilent (&rest body) ğŸ” Function: eask-dependencies () ğŸ” Function: eask-pkg-init (&optional force) ğŸ” Macro: eask-with-archives (archives &rest body) ğŸ” Function: eask-package-desc (name &optional current) ğŸ” Function: eask-argv (index) ğŸ” Function: eask-args () ğŸ” Variable: eask-file ğŸ” Variable: eask-file-root ğŸ” Function: eask-network-insecure-p () Function: eask-log-level-p () ğŸ” Function: eask-no-color-p () ğŸ” Function: eask-allow-error-p () ğŸ” Function: eask-insecure-p () ğŸ” Function: eask-proxy () ğŸ” Function: eask-http-proxy () ğŸ” Function: eask-https-proxy () ğŸ” Function: eask-no-proxy () ğŸ” Function: eask-destination () ğŸ” Function: eask-depth () ğŸ” Function: eask-verbose ()   ğŸš© Eask-file  ğŸ” Variable: eask-package Function: eask-package (name version description) ğŸ” Function: eask-package-file (file) ğŸ” Function: eask-files (pkg &rest args) ğŸ” Function: eask-depends-on (pkg &rest args) ğŸ” Function: eask-development (&rest dependencies) ğŸ” Function: eask-load-paths (&rest dirs) ğŸ” Function: eask-exec-paths (&rest dirs) ğŸ” Function: eask-source ğŸ” Function: eask-source-priority   ğŸš© Logging &rest args) ğŸ” Function: eask-log (msg &rest args) ğŸ” Function: eask-info (msg &rest args) ğŸ” Function: eask-warn (msg &rest args) ğŸ” Function: eask-error (msg &rest args) ğŸ” Function: eask-msg (msg &rest args) ğŸ” Function: eask-write (msg &rest args) ğŸ” Function: eask-report (&rest args)   ğŸš© File  ğŸ” Function: eask-guess-package-name () ğŸ” Function: eask-package-files () ğŸ” Function: eask-package-el-files () ğŸ” Function: eask-package-elc-files () ğŸ” Function: eask-package-multi-p () ğŸ” Function: eask-package-single-p () ğŸ” Function: eask-unpacked-size ()   ğŸš© Progress  ğŸ” Macro: eask-with-progress (msg-start body msg-end) ğŸ” Function: eask-print-log-buffer (&optional buffer-or-name)   ğŸš© Help  ğŸ” Function: eask-help (command)      ğŸš© Entry Point     ğŸ” Snippet: _prepare.el     Load lisp/_prepare.el to start using other Eask API.
(load (expand-file-name "../_prepare.el" (file-name-directory (nth 1 (member "-scriptload" command-line-args)))) nil t) Each Elisp scripts should have this snippet at the very top of the file.
ğŸ” Macro: eask-start (&rest body)     Command entry point. Each command file should contain this macro somewhere in the file.
(eask-start ;; TODO: design your command here! ) ğŸš© Core     ğŸ” Variable: eask-lisp-root     Points to lisp directory from the project root.
ğŸ” Function: eask-command ()     Return the current command in string.
ğŸ” Function: eask-special-p ()     Return t if the command that can be run without Eask-file existence.
This allow some commands can still be executed without defining the user directory. This can be handy when you want to do normal operations without touching the user directory.
ğŸ” Function: eask-checker-p ()     Return t if running Eask as the checker.
Without this flag, the process will be terminated once the error is occured. This flag allows you to run through operations without report error.
ğŸ” Function: eask-script (script)     Return full script filename.
(eask-script "extern/pacakge") ; {project-root}/lisp/extern/package.el ğŸ” Function: eask-load (script)     Load another eask script.
(eask-load "extern/ansi") ; load {project-root}/lisp/extern/ansi.el file ğŸ” Function: eask-call (script)     Call another eask script.
(eask-call "core/clean-elc") ; call command `eask clean-elc` ğŸ’¡ This is rarely used!  ğŸ” Macro: eask-defvc< (version &rest body)     Define scope if Emacs version is below specific version.
VERSION is an integer and will be compared with emacs-major-version.
(eask-defvc< 28 ;; This is missing before Emacs 28; define it (defvar package-native-compile nil) ) ğŸ’¡ This is used for Emacs compatibility!  ğŸ” Macro: eask–silent (&rest body)     Mute all messages from standard output inside the scope.
(eask--unsilent (message "You can't hear me! :(")) ğŸ” Macro: eask–unsilent (&rest body)     Unmute all messages from standard output inside the scope.
(eask--unsilent (message "You can hear me! :)")) ğŸ” Function: eask-dependencies ()     Return a list of dependencies.
Elements should either be (NAME . VERSION) or (NAME . RECIPE-FORMAT).
ğŸ” Function: eask-pkg-init (&optional force)     Initialize packages for use.
(eask-start (eask-pkg-init) ;; Now you can use packages installed in `package-user-dir' ) ğŸ’¡ This is usually called after eask-start!  ğŸ” Macro: eask-with-archives (archives &rest body)     Scope that temporary makes archives available.
ARCHIVES can either be a string or a list of strings.
(eask-with-archives "melpa" (eask-package-install 'package-build)) ; install packages that are only defined in MELPA ğŸ’¡ This is handy when you need certain packages from certain archives.  ğŸ” Function: eask-package-desc (name &optional current)     Build package descriptor for a package.
CURRENT means installed packages; otherwise it will return any available packages from selected package archives.
ğŸ” Function: eask-argv (index)     Return a command-line argument by index.
ğŸ” Function: eask-args ()     Return a list that is extracted from command-line arguments.
$ eask info --verbose 4 foo bar It will ignore --verbose and 4, and only returns foo, and bar.
ğŸ” Variable: eask-file     Path to currently loaded Eask-file.
ğŸ” Variable: eask-file-root     Directory to currently loaded Eask-file.
ğŸ” Function: eask-network-insecure-p ()     Return t if the current Emacs session allows insecure network connections.
ğŸš© Flags     ğŸ” Function: eask-global-p ()     Return t if the global option is enabled.
(if (eask-global-p) user-emacs-directory ; ~/.emacs.d user-emacs-directory) ; ./.eask/{emacs-version}/ ğŸ” Function: eask-force-p ()     Return t if the force option is enabled.
(package-delete .. (eask-force-p)) ğŸ” Function: eask-dev-p ()     Return t if the development option is enabled.
(when (eask-dev-p) (package-install 'ert-runner)) ; install development dependency ğŸ” Function: eask-debug-p ()     Return t if the debug option is enabled.
(when (eask-debug-p) (error "Executing in debug mode...")) ğŸ” Function: eask-strict-p ()     Return t if the strict option is enabled.
(setq byte-compile-error-on-warn (eask-strict-p)) ğŸ” Function: eask-timestamps-p ()     Return t/nil if the timestamps option is enabled/disabled.
These flags can’t co-exist in the same command.
(when (and (eask-timestamps-p) (eask-no-timestamps-p)) (error "This is impossible!")) ğŸ” Function: eask-log-level-p ()     Return t/nil if the log-level option is enabled/disabled.
These flags can’t co-exist in the same command.
(when (and (eask-log-level-p) (eask-no-log-level-p)) (error "This is impossible!")) ğŸ” Function: eask-no-color-p ()     Return t if the color option is enabled.
(unless (eask-no-color-p) (ansi-color-filter-apply "This string has no ansi code!")) ğŸ” Function: eask-allow-error-p ()     Return t if the allow-error option is enabled.
(unless (eask-allow-error-p) (error "Stop here.")) ğŸ” Function: eask-insecure-p ()     Return t if the insecure option is enabled.
(when (eask-insecure-p) ;; Do some dangerous tasks? ) ğŸ” Function: eask-proxy ()     ğŸ” Function: eask-http-proxy ()     ğŸ” Function: eask-https-proxy ()     ğŸ” Function: eask-no-proxy ()     Return a string represents hostname + port number.
$ eask [command] --proxy "localhost:1000" $ eask [command] --http-proxy "localhost:2000" $ eask [command] --https-proxy "localhost:3000" $ eask [command] --no-proxy "localhost:4000" ğŸ” Function: eask-destination ()     Return a string represents the destination (output path).
(write-file (or (eask-destination) "./dist")) ; write file to destination ğŸ” Function: eask-depth ()     Return an integer represents the depth of the current print level.
(setq print-level (eask-depth)) ğŸ” Function: eask-verbose ()     Return an integer represents the verbosity level.
(when (= (eask-verbose) 4) (setq byte-compile-verbose t)) ğŸš© Eask-file     These functions are the actual implementation of Eask-file DSL; and have the word eask- as the function prefix.
See DSL section for more information.
ğŸ” Variable: eask-package     It holds package’s NAME, VERSION, and DESCRIPTION in a plist.
(plist-get eask-package :name) ; return package name Three functions that are extended from this variable:
 (eask-package-name) (eask-package-version) (eask-package-description)  ğŸ” Variable: eask-package-file     Points to package main file.
ğŸ” Variable: eask-package-desc     Package descriptor from the package main file.
(package-desc-p eask-package-desc) ; return t âš  This can be nil if the package-descriptor cannot be constructed correctly!  ğŸ” Variable: eask-files     Holds a list of files pattern in wildcard specification.
ğŸ” Variable: eask-depends-on-emacs     Holds information about Emacs minimum version.
(depends-on "emacs" "26.1") Function will return Emacs version in string.
 (eask-depends-emacs-version) - return "26.1"  ğŸ” Variable: eask-depends-on     Holds a list of dependencies.
ğŸ” Variable: eask-depends-on-dev     Holds a list of dependencies that are development used.
ğŸ” Function: eask-package (name version description)     Alias of package.
ğŸ” Function: eask-package-file (file)     Alias of package-file.
ğŸ” Function: eask-files (pkg &rest args)     Alias of files.
ğŸ” Function: eask-depends-on (pkg &rest args)     Alias of depends-on.
ğŸ” Function: eask-development (&rest dependencies)     Alias of development.
ğŸ” Function: eask-load-paths (&rest dirs)     Alias of load-paths.
ğŸ” Function: eask-exec-paths (&rest dirs)     Alias of exec-paths.
ğŸ” Function: eask-source     Alias of source.
ğŸ” Function: eask-source-priority     Alias of source-priority.
ğŸš© Logging     Logger utility with timestamps and log level.
The log level value is defined in function eask--verb2lvl.
   Level Description Value     debug Designates fine-grained informational events that are most useful to debug an application. 4   log Designates normal messages. 3   info Designates informational messages that highlight the progress of the application at coarse-grained level. 2   warn Designates potentially harmful situations. 1   error Designates error events that might still allow the application to continue running. 0    The default level is log.
ğŸ” Variable: eask-verbosity     The verbosity level is represented as an integer.
(setq eask-verbosity 4) ; you could set from 0 to 4 ğŸ” Variable: eask-timestamps     Log messages with timestamps.
(setq eask-timestamps t) Output:
2022-04-14 13:44:46 This is a message with timestamps ğŸ” Variable: eask-log-level     Log messages with level.
(setq eask-log-level t) Output:
[DEBUG] This is a DEBUG message with log level ğŸ” Variable: eask-level-color     Define each log level color.
(setq eask-level-color '((debug . ansi-blue) (log . ansi-white) (info . ansi-cyan) (warn . ansi-yellow) (error . ansi-red))) ğŸ” Macro: eask-with-verbosity (symbol &rest body)     Define executions with the verbosity level.
(eask-with-verbosity 'debug ;; TODO: execution here.. ) Everything in the scope of this macro will be muted unless the verbosity reaches. It will only be printed when you have specified --verbose 4 global option.
ğŸ” Function: eask-debug (msg &rest args)     (eask-debug "This is DEBUG message") 2022-04-14 17:31:54 [DEBUG] This is DEBUG message ğŸ” Function: eask-log (msg &rest args)     (eask-log "This is LOG message") 2022-04-14 17:31:54 [LOG] This is LOG message ğŸ” Function: eask-info (msg &rest args)     (eask-info "This is INFO message") 2022-04-14 17:31:54 [INFO] This is INFO message ğŸ” Function: eask-warn (msg &rest args)     (eask-warn "This is WARNING message") 2022-04-14 17:31:54 [WARNING] This is WARNING message ğŸ” Function: eask-error (msg &rest args)     (eask-error "This is ERROR message") 2022-04-14 17:31:54 [ERROR] This is ERROR message ğŸ” Function: eask-msg (msg &rest args)     Like message function but will replace unicodes with color.
(eask-msg "Print this message with newline!") ğŸ” Function: eask-write (msg &rest args)     Like eask-msg function but without newline at the end.
(eask-write "Print this message without newline...") ğŸ” Function: eask-report (&rest args)     Report error/warning depends on strict flag.
(eask-report "This can be warning or error") See option –strict
ğŸš© File     ğŸ” Function: eask-guess-package-name ()     Return the possible package name.
ğŸ” Function: eask-package-files ()     Return a list of package files.
ğŸ” Function: eask-package-el-files ()     Return a list of package files with .el extension.
ğŸ” Function: eask-package-elc-files ()     Return a list of package files with .elc extension.
ğŸ” Function: eask-package-multi-p ()     Return nil if single file package.
ğŸ” Function: eask-package-single-p ()     Return t if single file package.
ğŸ” Function: eask-unpacked-size ()     Return size of the current package.
âš ï¸ This returns a string not bytes.  ğŸš© Progress     ğŸ” Macro: eask-with-progress (msg-start body msg-end)     Create execution with the responsive message output.
(eask-with-progress "Downloading files... " (eask-with-verbosity 'debug ; Often used with `eask-with-verbosity' ;; Execute some operations.. ) "done âœ“") Expect output:
Downloading files... done âœ“ ğŸ” Function: eask-print-log-buffer (&optional buffer-or-name)     Print buffer and highlight the errors and warnings.
(eask-print-log-buffer "*Package-Lint*") ğŸ’¡ This is handy for linters that create a buffer to display errors and warnings.  ğŸš© Help     ğŸ” Function: eask-help (command)     Print help manual located under lisp/help/ directory.
(eask-help 'search) ğŸ’¡ This is used when a command fails, and would like to give users some tips!

title: Troubleshooting
content:
This document helps you troubleshoot Eask.
   ğŸš© Possible Error Variables â›”ï¸ Error when running an Eask command      ğŸš© Possible Error Variables     Some potential variables can cause faulty Eask, please check
 Emacs is installed and set up with PATH Eask is installed correctly Node version should be 14.x or above  â›”ï¸ Error when running an Eask command     If you run an Eask command and get an error, there are a few things you can try yourself:
 Make sure that you have the latest Eask version. You can determine the current Eask version with eask --version. Upgrade Eask with eask upgrade-eask or npm install -g @emacs-eask/eask@latest if you chose to install from npm.  âš  Warning
If you installed Eask with npm, then you should probably upgrade it through npm. Otherwise, you would just have to ensure the git is installed.
  If the error persists, try to reinstall Eask from scratch.  If Eask still does not work, please report an issue to the issue tracker. Please include Eask output with the [–verbose 4] and [–debug] options enabled, to give us as much information as possible.

title: FAQ
content:
Here is a list of general frequently asked questions.
   â“ Why Node.JS? â“ Who should use this tool? â“ Why yargs? â“ Why am I getting the error package target tar/el not found while installing? â“ Why am I getting the error package is not installable? â“ Why am I getting git errors with status 2?      â“ Why Node.JS?     Node has better support on all kinds of terminal applications (compare to just the shell script)! Like colorful interface, entire npm community, etc. So you can build cross-platform software with fewer hassles! Especially after Microsoft had bought the NPM inc, and would likely support their own system well.
Cask does not seem to support Windows (no WSL) after version 0.8.6. In the early versions, they have used Python, but due to the Python supports on Windows are just not as good as Node.JS.
â“ Who should use this tool?     People who like to use Emacs on Windows (no WSL), and would like to keep their Emacs configuration/packages consistent on every operating system!
â“ Why yargs?     yargs has a very wide community; and it has been used in many tools. It’s cross-platform! And most importantly, this is one of the tools that work well on Linux, macOS, and Windows.
There is also the major difference compared with Eask and other alternatives. Cask, makem.sh, or Eldev rely more on batch and bash. We chose a different route and would like to hand over heavy tasks to a high-level programming language, JavaScript. The development simply became easier, since we don’t need to care about different types of shells anymore!
The drawback is the NodeJS runtime, but we can simply pack the entire CLI program into an executable! That way we would not need to install Node and npm before using eask!
â“ Why am I getting the error package target tar/el not found while installing?     The example error message,
http://melpa.org/packages/lsp-mode-20220429.647.tar: Not found The issue is caused by the mismatch from the backup archives. Generally, Eask will pick up the latest archive-contents from sources unless you have been pinging sources too many times. Then the source could block your IP for few minutes.
You can either wait for few minutes for the source to remove you from their black list. Or wait for the backup archives to update to the latest version. The backup archives repository is here.
â“ Why am I getting the error package is not installable?     The example error message,
Package not installable `helm'; make sure package archives are included You would need to first ask yourself; where does the package came from and what specific source holds this package information. From the above example message, helm is listed on the melpa source. You would have to edit your Eask-file like this:
... (source "melpa") ; <- add this line (depends-on "helm") â“ Why am I getting git errors with status 2?     If you get this sample error message
Loading package information... done âœ“ - Installing s (20210616.619)... Failed (status 2): git --no-pager remote get-url upstream . ... You may have bug-reference-prog-mode enabled. It is not yet compatible with Eask and should be disabled when running any of Easkâ€™s commands.
See this issue for more information.

title: Introduction
content:
Eask is a command-line tool that helps you build, lint, and test Emacs Lisp packages. It creates a clean environment to sandbox your elisp code without influencing your personal configuration. Eask aims to be:
 Consistent enough to sandbox across all systems General enough to have Emacsers often use commands (byte-compile, checkdoc, etc) Robust enough to provide useful results even in the presence of user’s errors Dependency-free so that the tool can be run on any platform  â“ Why Eask?     Eask is heavily inspired by Cask, so they are somewhat related! This tool focuses on consistency! Cask and makem.sh both rely on bash which Windows doesn’t run on by default. If you use WSL or other environment system file Cygwin/MSYS ; then this may not be the tool you are looking for! ğŸ‘€
âš–ï¸ Comparisons     The table were compiled by reading these projectsâ€™ documentation and source code, but the author is not an expert on these tools. Corrections are welcome.
    Behind technology Cross-Platform Emacs Version Size     Cask Bash, Batch, and Python (Windows) âŒ Good on Linux and macOS, but it’s particularly bad on Windows 24.5+ 3,000+ lines   makem.sh Shellscript âŒ Doesn’t work on Windows by default 26.1+ 1 file, 1200+ lines   Eldev Bash, Batch, and Powershel, etc âœ” Good, but qutie slow on Windows 24.4+ 4,000+ lines   Eask Node or Native Executables âœ” Good, and it can be compiled to native executables 26.1+ 3,000+ lines    ğŸ’¡ makem.sh has a good comparisons document as well, visit their site  ğŸ“° News      0.7.x - Fix default-directory isn’t honored by -g option 0.6.x - You can now use eask create to create an Elisp project 0.5.x - Handle error for failed archive 0.4.x - Add color logger 0.3.x - Add verbosity level and timestamps 0.2.x - Done basic error handling with exit code at the end of executions 0.1.39 - Use spawn instead exec; now messages will be printed immediately 0.1.x - Project bare-bones are pretty much complete!  ğŸ“ Todo list     Development      [DEV] Publish package to homebrew [DEV] Publish package to Chocolatety [DEV] Publish package to Scoop [DEV] Publish package to MacPorts  Core commands      [FEAT] Add publish command; to publish package to eask archive?  Eask-file commands      [FEAT] Add add-source command  Linter      [FEAT] Add elisp-lint command  Testing      [FEAT] Add ecukes command  ğŸ“‚ Underlying Projects     The design of Eask was greatly influenced by the following projects:
 cask - Project management tool for Emacs makem.sh - Makefile-like script for building and testing Emacs Lisp packages epm - Emacs Package Manager eldev - Elisp Development Tool

title: â“ How to Contribute
content:
âšœï¸ Code of Conduct ğŸª‘ Open Development ğŸ“Œ Semantic Versioning ğŸ’¡ Branch Organization ğŸ“‚ State of the project      âšœï¸ Code of Conduct     We have adopted the Contributor Covenant as its Code of Conduct, and we expect project participants to adhere to it. Please read the full text so that you can understand what actions will and will not be tolerated.
ğŸª‘ Open Development     All work on Eask happens directly on GitHub. Both core team members and external contributors send pull requests which go through the same review process.
ğŸ“Œ Semantic Versioning     Eask follows semantic versioning. We release patch versions for critical bugfixes, minor versions for new features or non-essential changes, and major versions for any breaking changes. When we make breaking changes, we also introduce deprecation warnings in a minor version so that our users learn about the upcoming changes and migrate their code in advance.
Every significant change is documented in the changelog file.
ğŸ’¡ Branch Organization     Submit all changes directly to the master branch. We donâ€™t use separate branches for development or for upcoming releases. We do our best to keep master in good shape, with all tests passing.
Code that lands in master must be compatible with the latest stable release. It may contain additional features, but no breaking changes. We should be able to release a new minor version from the tip of master at any time.
ğŸ“‚ State of the project     The project’s bare-bones are pretty much done, we are currently looking for contributors to give us feedback and improve our TUI/UX for this tool!
We are also looking for advice to add more. Emacser often use commands and options, so these features are prepared by default! Like command lint (package-lint) or option --debug refers to debug-on-error to t!
